assetIdentification.assetDescription: Control vehicle door locks through IVI system

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that door lock control commands cannot be maliciously modified or spoofed
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Prevent unauthorized entities from manipulating door lock state

cybersecurityProperties.description: Ensures that door lock control functionality remains available to legitimate users
cybersecurityProperties.protectionGoal: Maintain door security functionality during vehicle operation

threatScenarios.title: Spoofed Door Unlock Commands
threatScenarios.description: An attacker gains access to the in-vehicle network and injects spoofed door unlock commands to the Body Control Module, causing unauthorized door unlocking

initialAccess.method: Physical access to OBD-II port or wireless access to in-vehicle network

steps.description: Gain access to the vehicle's CAN bus network
steps.technique: Connect to OBD-II port or exploit wireless entry point

steps.description: Analyze CAN traffic to identify door lock control messages
steps.technique: CAN bus sniffing and message analysis

steps.description: Craft spoofed door unlock command with correct format
steps.technique: Packet crafting based on observed message patterns

steps.description: Inject spoofed command onto CAN bus

unsafeControlActions: Door unlock command sent when vehicle is in motion
Door unlock command sent without driver authorization
controlFlaws: No authentication of unlock command source
No validation of vehicle state before command execution
No contextual awareness in command processing

attackFeasibility.justification: Physical access to the vehicle is required, along with specialized knowledge and equipment to analyze and inject CAN messages

relevantVulnerabilities.description: Insufficient message authentication in automotive CAN bus implementation
Missing input validation in BCM firmware allows message spoofing

existingControls.description: Basic CAN message filtering in BCM
Network segmentation between infotainment and body control domains

threatScenarios.title: Replay Attack on Door Unlock Commands
threatScenarios.description: An attacker captures legitimate door unlock commands sent over the in-vehicle network and replays them later to gain unauthorized access to the vehicle

initialAccess.method: Physical access to CAN bus or proximity to vehicle during legitimate door lock operation

steps.description: Gain access to the vehicle's CAN bus network
steps.technique: Connect to OBD-II port or exploit wireless entry point

steps.description: Record CAN traffic during legitimate door unlock operation
steps.technique: CAN bus sniffing and message logging

steps.description: Wait for vehicle to be locked and secured
Replay recorded door unlock command sequence
steps.technique: Exact reproduction of previously captured legitimate messages

unsafeControlActions: Door unlock command accepted when not freshly generated
Door unlock command processed without verification of timeliness
controlFlaws: No timestamp or nonce in unlock commands
No challenge-response mechanism for command verification
No session context for command validation

attackFeasibility.justification: Requires initial access to record messages, but replay execution is straightforward with minimal technical knowledge once messages are captured

relevantVulnerabilities.description: Lack of replay protection in automotive access control systems
Missing timestamp verification in door control commands

existingControls.description: Partial message encryption for sensitive commands

threatScenarios.title: Denial of Service on Door Lock Control
threatScenarios.description: An attacker floods the CAN bus with high-priority messages, preventing legitimate door lock control messages from being processed and effectively disabling door lock functionality

initialAccess.method: Physical access to OBD-II port or wireless access to in-vehicle network

steps.description: Gain access to the vehicle's CAN bus network
steps.technique: Connect to OBD-II port or exploit wireless entry point

steps.description: Generate flood of high-priority messages on CAN bus
Maintain flood to prevent normal operation

unsafeControlActions: Door lock control commands not received by BCM
Door lock control functionality unavailable during emergency
controlFlaws: No prioritization mechanism for critical messages
Insufficient bandwidth allocation for security-critical functions
No redundant communication paths for critical commands

attackFeasibility.justification: Basic technical knowledge is sufficient to execute a DoS attack once access to the CAN bus is obtained, as CAN has minimal built-in DoS protection

relevantVulnerabilities.description: CAN bus susceptibility to denial of service through message flooding
Lack of rate limiting in vehicle gateway allows traffic flooding

existingControls.description: Basic input rate limiting in BCM
Error counter implementation in CAN controller

relatedStandards.description: Systems Theoretic Process Analysis for Security

relatedRequirements.description: The door locking system shall maintain door security even in the presence of malformed CAN messages
The door locking system shall complete a lock/unlock command within 500ms of user initiation under normal operating conditions
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Ensure availability of door security functions

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall verify the integrity of door lock/unlock commands before execution
relatedRequirements.cybersecurityGoal: Prevent tampering with door lock commands

relatedRequirements.description: The system shall require authentication for door lock/unlock commands from the IVI interface

keyTerms.Replay Attack: Attack where valid data transmission is maliciously repeated
keyTerms.Message Authentication: Verification of message origin and integrity

contentSummary: Threat scenarios for Door Lock Control Interface addressing three key threats: spoofed door unlock commands (TS-DOOR-01), replay attacks on door commands (TS-DOOR-02), and denial of service attacks (TS-DOOR-03). Each scenario details the attack vector, steps, control flaws per STPA methodology, and attack feasibility assessment using CVSS. Attack feasibility ratings range from MEDIUM for spoofing and replay attacks to HIGH for denial of service attacks. All scenarios show insufficient existing controls, requiring additional security measures as identified in the complementary risk assessment document.
